hero.title: Complete Guide to Cattle & Buffalo
hero.subtitle: Discover comprehensive information about cattle and buffalo breeds, their characteristics, care requirements, and everything you need to know about these remarkable livestock animals.

cattle.title: Cattle (Cows)
cattle.desc: Cattle (Bos taurus) are domesticated bovines primarily raised for milk, meat, and leather. They are intelligent social animals with complex behavioral patterns and have been human companions for over 10,000 years, playing crucial roles in agriculture and food production worldwide.

buffalo.title: Water Buffalo
buffalo.desc: Water buffalo (Bubalus bubalis) are large bovines perfectly adapted to hot climates and wet conditions. They produce exceptionally rich milk with higher fat content and are excellent for dairy farming in tropical and subtropical regions around the world.

insights.title: Key Insights
insights.buffalo: Buffalo milk contains significantly higher fat content (6-8% vs 3.5-4.5%), making it ideal for producing rich dairy products like ghee, cheese, and traditional sweets.
insights.cow: Cow milk has a lighter consistency and milder taste, making it more suitable for direct consumption, especially for children and health-conscious consumers.

cow.name: Cow
cow.description: Dairy and beef cattle are essential livestock providing milk, meat, and leather products.

buffalo.name: Buffalo
buffalo.description: Water buffalo are important for milk production and agricultural work in many tropical regions.

mastitis.name: Mastitis
mastitis.description: Inflammation of the mammary gland, most commonly caused by bacterial infection.
mastitis.funFact: Mastitis costs dairy farmers billions globally each year in lost milk production.

bloat.name: Bloat (Gas)
bloat.description: Excessive accumulation of gas in the rumen causing dangerous abdominal distension.
bloat.funFact: A cow can produce up to 500 liters of gas per day normally, but bloat prevents proper gas release.

milkFever.name: Milk Fever (Hypocalcemia)
milkFever.description: Metabolic disorder caused by low blood calcium levels, typically occurring around calving.
milkFever.funFact: Despite its name, milk fever rarely involves fever - the body temperature often drops.

lameness.name: Lameness
lameness.description: Impaired locomotion affecting one or more limbs, significantly impacting animal welfare.
lameness.funFact: Lameness is the third most costly disease in dairy cattle after mastitis and reproductive disorders.

diarrhea.name: Diarrhea
diarrhea.description: Frequent passage of loose, watery stools often indicating digestive system problems.
diarrhea.funFact: Calf diarrhea is responsible for more deaths in young calves than any other disease.

heatStress.name: Heat Stress
heatStress.description: Physiological strain caused by high environmental temperature and humidity.
heatStress.funFact: Buffalo can regulate body temperature by wallowing in mud, which acts as natural sunscreen.

footRot.name: Foot Rot
footRot.description: Bacterial infection of the hoof causing severe lameness and foul odor.
footRot.funFact: Foot rot can spread rapidly through a herd in wet, muddy conditions.

respiratoryInfection.name: Respiratory Infection
respiratoryInfection.description: Infections affecting the respiratory system, commonly caused by viruses or bacteria.
respiratoryInfection.funFact: Buffalo are generally more resistant to respiratory diseases than cattle due to their robust immune system.

parasites.name: Internal Parasites
parasites.description: Worm infestations that can significantly impact health and productivity.
parasites.funFact: Buffalo can harbor over 50 different species of internal parasites, but many show high resistance.

digestiveDisorders.name: Digestive Disorders
digestiveDisorders.description: Various conditions affecting the digestive system and nutrient absorption.
digestiveDisorders.funFact: Buffalo have a more efficient digestive system than cattle, converting poor-quality feed better.

hero.subtitle: Follow this comprehensive guide to accurately classify and score your animals using our AI-powered system.

requirements.title: Requirements
items: Stable internet connection for image processing

proTips.title: Pro Tips
items: Take photos during golden hour (early morning/late afternoon) for best lighting
Use a tripod or stabilizer for consistent framing
Allow 2-3 minutes between shots for animal to relax
Keep backup photos in case of blurry images

process.title: Classification Process
process.subtitle: Follow these detailed steps to ensure accurate animal classification and scoring results.

aruco.caption: Add a Aruco marker for scale reference image for accurate measurements

1.title: Prepare Your Animal
1.description: Position your animal in a clean, well-lit environment for optimal photo quality
details: Ensure good natural lighting or use proper artificial lighting
Position the animal on level ground with clear background
Make sure the animal is calm and standing naturally
Remove any obstructions or distracting elements from the background
Add a Aruco marker for scale reference image for accurate measurements

tips.text: Best results are achieved during daylight hours with the animal standing relaxed.

2.title: Capture Three Angle Photos
2.description: Take clear photos from front, side, and rear angles for comprehensive analysis
details: Front View: Capture head-on shot showing face and front body structure
Side View: Take a profile shot showing the complete side body structure
Rear View: Photograph from behind showing hindquarters and rear structure
Place the Aruco marker in each shot for scale measurements
Maintain consistent distance (3-5 meters) for all three shots
2.tips: Keep the camera at the same height as the animal's midsection for accurate proportions.

3.title: Upload Images
3.description: Upload your three photos using the mobile interface
details: Open the Gopalan AI
Navigate to the 'New Classification' section
Upload photos in the correct sequence: Front → Side → Rear
Ensure each image is clear and properly oriented
3.tips: Images should be at least 1024x768 pixels for best analysis results.

4.title: Mark Measurement Points
4.description: Place two reference points on each image for accurate measurements
details: Tap on the image to place the first measurement point
Place the second point to create a reference measurement line
Common reference points: shoulder height, body length, chest girth
Follow the on-screen guidance for optimal point placement
4.tips: Use anatomical landmarks like shoulder blade or hip bone for consistent measurements.

5.title: Review Classification Results
5.description: Analyze the AI-generated breed classification and scoring results
details: View breed identification with confidence percentage
Check body condition scoring and measurements
Review genetic trait analysis and recommendations
Save results to your animal records database
5.tips: Results accuracy improves with better photo quality and proper measurement point placement.
